title: Boeing Reports $3.3 Billion Loss, Weighed Down By Defense Unit Charges; Revenue rises by 4% as CEO David Calhoun says turnarounds take time
text:
The company said it generated $2.9 billion in free cash in the third quarter, keeping it on track to end the year with positive cash flow.

The per-share of loss of $5.49 compared with a 19-cent deficit a year earlier.

Boeing shares rose around 1% in pre-market trading early Wednesday.

Chief Executive David Calhoun said the company was making strides in its turnaround effort but still faced challenges. The company has faced a series of engineering, manufacturing and regulatory problems since two of its 737 MAX jets crashed in 2018 and 2019, taking 346 lives.

"Turnarounds take time—and we have more work to do—but I am confident in our team and the actions we're taking for the future," he said in an internal message to employees Wednesday.

The company's commercial jet business has dealt with supply chain disruptions, including for new engines, that have hindered deliveries of 737 jets.

It also has faced regulatory hurdles with the latest versions of the 737, the shorter MAX 7 and longer MAX 10 models. Both have a year-end legal deadline to win certification by U.S. air-safety regulators. Without a congressional extension of that deadline, federal law may require Boeing to make costly and time-consuming overhauls to the airplanes' cockpits.

Write to Andrew Tangel at andrew.tangel@wsj.com

Boeing Reports $3.3 Billion Loss, Weighed Down By Defense Unit Charges
